div3.head: The State of the country.
div3.p:
The signs of the times do not improve; but, on the contrary appear to grow worse daily.
Their effect upon the people of this city is peculiarly striking.
There are hundreds of gentlemen here, who, three weeks ago, were strong Union men, and some of whom talked freely about the hanging of secessionists, who are now decidedly in favor of a dissolution of the Confederacy without delay; and even the most ardent lovers of the Union are driven to the borders of despair.
The man, indeed, who has any hope of its preservation is rarely met with.
The general opinion seems to be--first that a dissolution is almost beyond perad venture; second, that it we must separate, the sooner the better for the peace of all the States, and for the industry and commerce of all.

There seems to be little disposition to speculate upon projects for saving the Union. --The President's Message is regarded as a useless document, animadverting upon the means of avoiding an event which, in a moral sense, has already occurred, and whose fulfillment, politically and physically, is progressing with as much rapidity as is possible for constitutional proceedings.
From all that we can see and hear, we can come to no other conclusion with reference to the public mind.

The distinguished Secretary of War (whose letter to the editor of the Enquirer we notice to-day,) will find that his own opinion that there is no hope left for the Union, but concurs with the general conviction, at least in this part of Virginia.

But the nature of the event — its magnitude and moment — demand that the most powerful and astute minds of the country shall be called to devise the means of a fair and peaceable separation, if possible.
Virginia has more and deeper interests at stake than any other State, and she ought to make the matter one of serious and constant reflection.
Promptness is demanded.
If there is the remotest hope of saving the Union, then there is no time to be lost.
If there is not, it is of the highest importance for our future destiny, that the step of separation shall be properly and wisely directed.
We cannot separate Virginia from the South, no more than we Virginians can separate ourselves from the fate of our honored and beloved mother.
People every where should deliberate earnestly upon the position of affairs, and the leading minds of the State should study the subject with devoted attention in the brief interval of time before our State will be compelled to act her part in the National drama now transpiring.

div3.head: The Virginia Dare — meeting of Stockholders and others.
div3.p:
A very large and agreeable party of gentlemen, composed of the stockholders and others of the new Virginia and Liverpool packet line, assembled yesterday on board the good ship Virginia Dare, and partook of an elegant collation which had been prepared for the occasion.
Toasts were drunk, and patriotic, appropriate and eloquent speeches made.
We never saw a happier company.
All were delighted with the noble vessel, and proud and hopeful of the great enterprise upon which Virginia has so gallantly entered.
We observed that while the festivities were in progress, the crew were busily employed in getting in the heavy hogsheads of tobacco, and other articles, amounting to much more than a cargo for one vessel, which is ready for transportation.
This is a glorious beginning, and we see no reason to doubt that it will lead in time to a more glorious result — the entire commercial independence of Virginia.
Indeed, among the first acts of the stockholders, in assembling on board yesterday, was the adoption of a resolution to build another vessel, the work upon which will be immediately commenced.
The enter prising and spirited resolve will be hailed with enthusiastic acclamations by the whole community, and indicates a spirit which ought to rally to its support every Southern man who has a spark of patriotism in his bosom, and who desires to show his faith by his works, and to prove his love of the South by deeds instead of words.

In this connection, it gives us pleasure to render tribute to the noble public spirit manifested by our enterprising fellow citizen, Ed. Wm. De Voss, Esq., who purchased that new and splendid bark, the " Pioneer," which has performed two trips across the ocean, with full cargoes, and has just cleared with a third for Liverpool.
In a ship-yard nearly opposite the place where the Virginia Dare is lying, a vessel even larger is building, also intended for the Richmond and Liverpool trade, and which will probably be the finest ship that ever graced the Virginia waters, and which is the sole property of Messrs. De Voss & Co. Where all the wealthy men of the South to exhibit he wise and noble liberality of Mr. De Voss, we should need no more political speeches and resolutions to regenerate Virginia, and ensure Southern independence.

div3.head: Reconstruction of Navies.
div3.p:
It cannot be doubted that Louis Napoleon has caused England more anxiety and expense than any other potentate of the earth since the days of his uncle.
Let it be borne in mind that a hundred millions a year is the estimated cost to England of an actual war between England and France, and that she is now compelled, in order to be prepared for such a war, to spend seventy millions a year, and we may ask whether Napoleon is not already having his revenge, in a quiet way, for Waterloo?
It strikes us that it would be better economy to spend a hundred millions in actual fighting, and take the chances of destroying the cause of this immense annual expenditure, than to let it go on from year to year, and last as long, probably, as the life of the present Emperor of the French.
If it be true, as Napoleon avers, that he has not increased the military and naval expenditures of, France beyond those which her ordinary establishment requires, he enjoys the singular felicity of himself escaping all the burdens of war, and heaping war expenses upon the shoulders of Great Britain, which she is compelled to carry without any of the compensating advantages of actual hostilities.

One of the heaviest and most annoying sources of expenditures to which England is forced by her apprehensions of the French Emperor, is that which is required by the necessities of her navy.
She had long been the acknowledged mistress of the Channel, and at the close of the great wars with Napoleon had a thousand ships-of-war.
So long as the era of sailing vessels continued, there was no earthly chance for France to dispute her naval supremacy, or to render an invasion of Great Britain possible.
France might build ships, but she could not make seamen, and Britain looked with calm contempt upon the enlargement of the French navy.
But when steam was introduced in ships-of-war, and Napoleon began to adopt it generally in the naval service of France, then the troubles of Great Britain commenced, and her money began to flow like water.
Her vast sailing establishment was no longer a defence; the advantages of that immense superiority over France in nautical aptitude and skill which had been her glory and safeguard, were at once paralyzed.
She at once saw that steam would introduce into naval warfare the precision, certainty, and system of military movements, and that a soldier would be almost as good as a sailor to command a squadron of steamboats.
Immediately she commenced the costly work of overhauling her whole navy, converting sailing vessels into steamers, fitting them up with steam machinery, and building new and powerful steamships.
The labor and expense of the undertaking was like building an entirely new navy.
But Great Britain never balks with either work or money when her national pride and security are concerned; and so, after an enormous expenditure, she was again in a position to overwhelm, by supremacy of numbers and metal, any attempt of France to dispute her dominion of the sees, or to make a descent upon her "tight little Island." John Bull now felt once more at his case grumbling savagely at the cost he had been put to, but still proud of the result.
Scarcely, however, had he buttoned up his pockets, when it was announced that his restless and inventive neighbor over the way, who seems to have been born for no other purpose than to keep John Bull on the tauter hooks of anxiety, and to drain his pockets of their loose change, was constructing three terrific engines for maritime warfare, armed with iron prows and covered with steel.
There was no help for it, and England was compelled to build as many monsters of the same kind as Louis Napoleon, and the English press is now discussing the question whether England shall once more submit to an enormous increase of naval expenditure in order to rival her ambitions neighbor.
The Government has apparently decided in favor of converting the naval vessels of England from wood to iron, as the fact is announced semi-officially (in the Army and Navy Gazette) that "the Comptroller of the Navy is most anxious not to be behind in the race which France bids fair to run with us in the building of iron steamships," and that "any apparent delay which has taken place in giving orders for the construction of a further number of formidable but most expensive ships, proceeds merely from a desire on his part to be convinced that he possesses the plans and models of vessels best calculated not only to act as engines of warfare, but as safe sea boats."

Another prominent London newspaper pronounces this the most important naval problem that has arisen since the application of steam to men-of-war; and another journal says, "We may lament a vast and possibly useless outlay, but we must not run the remotest risk of being overmatched." Captain Halsted, R. N., whose views command much respect, is said to express the opinion that no sort of artillery is of any value against ships protected in this manner; while, on the other hand, Mr. Jos. Whitworth, the inventor of the celebrated gun bearing his name, holds views almost diametrically opposed.
In a communication to the London Times, he says:

q.p:
"There is no doubt but that ships may be built which are proof against ordinary shot, but my experience leads me to believe that the penetration of armor plates is a question of firing against them a projectile under the proper combined conditions; these are, that it shall be of the proper shape, material and weight, and have the requisite velocity.
A flat-fronted projectile of properly hardened material, and weighing less than an ounce, fired from one of my ordinary rifles, will penetrate wrought iron plates 6-10ths of an inch thick.
Again, plates four inches thick are penetrated by the 80lb projectiles, and I have no doubt but that the 6-inch plates would be penetrated by heavier projectiles with a more powerful gun.--Increased thickness of plate, then, is to be overcome by increased power of gun; and the question is, in which case will the capability of increase sooner reach its limits?
Ships which are hampered by the weight of enormous plates are so overburdened that they are unfit to carry a broadside of guns heavy enough to penetrate the armor of vessels plated similarly to themselves — Again, a ship constructed to carry very thick plates cannot be driven at the high speed which must hereafter give the superiority in naval warfare."

div3.p:
It is urged, moreover, that war vessels of this description are as much exposed as any others to the effects of bombshells falling perpendicularly upon their decks; they are vulnerable through their port-holes; are liable to roll more than timber ships, from excessive top- weight; and the combination of speed with great weight of metal is a point particularly difficult of attainment.
Sir Howard Douglas, high authority, gives his opinion that "there is little to dread from these unwieldy, flat-bottomed, top- weighted, heavily-rolling craft, in the open sea," and recommends that the public money should be employed in forging new engines and bolts of war, rather than in vain attempts to render ships proof against them.
If the United States is "behind the age," in the extent of its naval force, it at least enjoys the advantages of not being compelled to undo, in any considerable measure, that which it has already done, and of being in a position to avail itself, without much inconvenience or expense, of the results of the experience and experiments of Europe.

div3.head: The Prince's visit to America.
div3.p: contains the following paragraph:

q.p:
"Lord Lyons had returned to Washington.
He states that the Prince of Wales was highly delighted with his trip in the United States, nothing having occurred during his entire journey to mar for one moment its pleasures."

div3.p:
As this remark includes the Prince's visit to this city, of course it is a contradiction of the lies published by the editor of the New York Times, and copied from his columns by the London Times and the Post, and made by those journals the occasion of heaping bitter denunciations upon this whole community.
Raymond has the name of liar branded in his forehead.
He is a meaner man than Greeley, because he is a sneak.
Greeley is an open and unblushing rascal.
He lies boldly and bolsters his mendacity unhesitatingly.
Raymond Is a cunning, insidious libeler, who, assuming the air of moderation and fairness, perpetrates the grossest misrepresentations and vilest calumnies of Southern communities.
The day may come when both these execrable men will pay the penalty of the evils they have contributed so largely to bring upon their country.

div3.head: Mr. Baldwin's Lecture.
div3.p:
Mr. Baldwin's Lecture on "Cockney Travelers and others, " which was postponed some days since on account of the weather, will be delivered to-night, at the Mechanics' Institute.
The Lecture is seasonable, and we have no doubt it will afford a great deal of pleasure to those who hear it. The subject of visitors to our country, and what they say of us, always one of interest and sometimes of excitement to us, is just now especially attractive.
We have fortunately learned how now to regard all that is said of us with composure, and to criticise our critics.
Mr. Baldwin will present them in a fair light, and, we are sure, in a most entertaining manner.

Edmund About, the French author, had a duel on hand when last heard from.
His contemporaries are envious, and are constantly provoking him.
A. Todd, mail agent for many years on the Greenville (S. C.) Railroad, died suddenly on the road on the 3d inst.

div3.head: Mission Chapel Fair.
div3.p: --The Ladies of Centenary and other Methodist Churches of the city, will hold this week, at the Mechanics' Institute, commencing this Evening, a Fair and Feast, for the purpose of raising means to build a Chapel, on Marshal street, near Buchanan's Spring.

It is very many years since such an appeal to the public has been made by the Methodists of the city, and as a large number of Ornamental and Useful Articles will be offered for sale, a liberal encouragement is anticipated.
The Christmas holidays are at hand, and ladies and gentlemen can supply themselves with presents for their little and large friends.
A table well supplied with Refreshments will be spread day and night for the accommodation of visitors.
All interested will please send or bring their contributions to the Hall during the day.
The managers earnestly invite the co-operation of all the Methodists of the city and vicinage and solicit the attendance of the good people of the town generally.
The Fair room will be well lighted and warmed every evening, and will be open for visitors during the day. de 3--ts

It is all important that the meeting be a full one, and Stockholders are earnestly requested to attend in person if possible; otherwise by proxy.

div3.head: A Card.
div3.p: --In explanation of the card of P. Rahm, which appeared in the Whig of the 6th inst., I hereby lay before the public the following note, addressed by me to him yesterday.

Philip Rahm, Esq.--Sir: I decline releasing you as my endorser (although of disrepute to my paper) for six hundred dollars. At the proper time you shall be released, at which time I shall demand the collateral placed in your hands to secure you against any loss, even in the event of your having the obligation to pay. As you cannot provide for the payment of your own obligations, rest assured, sir, that I can and will mine.
de 7--1t Respectfully,Jas. E. Goddin.

div3.p:
--to Emily Jackson Brown.
Take notice that on the 15th of January, 1861, at the office of A. Judson Crane, Esq., in the city of Richmond, Va., between the hours of 9 A. M. and 6 P. M., I shall proceed to take the deposition of John W. Branch and others, to be read as evidence in a suit now pending in the Circuit Court of the said city, wherein I am plaintiff and you are defendant.
If the taking thereof be not completed on that day, the taking thereof will be continued from day to day until completed.

div3.head: Virginia City, on Norfolk harbor
div3.p:
--Located on deep water, above the Navy Yard, high, healthy, central; on the inside of the harbor, and unsurpassed for ready business facilities, by two grand Trunk Railroads ramifying into all the Southern and Western States, two Steamboat and Ship Canals, and the best harbor in the world ! Lots now only $60--$145 in monthly payments of $5--the greatest portion of the clear receipts to be appropriated for manufacturing purposes, for which a company has been chartered, (capital, $500,000; shares, $500 each;) in which all friends of manufacturing industry in this locality are invited to participate.
Another portion of the receipts for lots to be appropriated for street and other public improvements.
For particulars, and subscription for Lots or Manufacturing Stocks, apply to Office Virginia City Company, 21 Main st., Norfolk, Va. Wm. Schmooze, Pres't.

div3.head: Notice to Tax Payers.
div3.p: --Pursuant to an ordinance passed 11th January, 1855, I will attend at the Collector's Office, in the City Hall, from the 15th to the 31st December, inclusive, to receive the remaining half of taxes from such persons as are entitled to a deduction of 10 per cent., by having previously paid the first half in June last, in accordance with said ordinance.
Julius A. Hosson, C. C. R.

N. B.--It will be seen from the above that the Collector is required to attend at the Office from the 15th to the 31st of the month, to receive taxes remaining due from June last Before the January term of the Hustings Court, he is required, by ordinance, to advertise delinquent real estate to be sold for non-payment of taxes.
Persons who have not done so will see the necessity of calling and paying these taxes, as it will be impossible for the Collector to call on them before he advertises.
de 1--1m J. A. H., C. C. R.

div3.head: Watt's Cuff-Brace Ploughs,
div3.p: Geo. Watt & Co.--Established in 1845.

George Watt has obtained, at different times, four separate patents on his Cuff-Brace Ploughs, acknowledged to embrace the most reliable improvements ever made on this implement, three of which patents have to run respectively ten, twelve and thirteen years, and has been awarded at the late Mechantes' Fair in Richmond a certificate of Silver Medal, for continued superiority in Ploughs, (the highest premiums given,) and at the last State Fair premium on the same, in addition to premiums awarded at all the preceding Fairs for years.

Within two months past he has added other valuable improvements, and we now invite all in want of Ploughs, warranted in every respect superior to others, to call and examine our large and varied stock of Ploughs, Castings and Agricultural implements, and fresh and prime Garden and Field Seeds, &c., which we offer for sale on our usual accommodating terms.

div3.head: Wanted

You can paint your own portrait that will look as natural as life, by learning this art; learnt in five lessons.
Terms, $10. This amount will cover the whole bill of learning this art perfectly.

div3.head: [Special Dispatch to the Richmond Dispatch.]
div3.p: No "Concessions" to be Made by the Republicans--The Special Committee a Farce — A Treasury Draft Dishonored, &c. Washington, Dec. 6.--The best authority reports that the Republican Senators held a us last night, and resolved to make no concession.

Southern members pronounces the House Special committee a farce.
There is not a representative man on it.
The National Intelligencer of to-morrow comes out for a Convention of all the Southern States.
A draft of the Clerk of the House on the Treasury for the Clerk of the House on the Treasury for $10,000, to pay its subordinates, has been dishonored.
Sixty thousand dollars due the 1st of next January for pensions have been ordered not to be paid, unless the Treasury notes will be issued promptly.
None of the clerks in the Departments will receive a dollar for their present month's services. Z.

div3.head: Congressional.
div3.p: Washington, Dec. 6. --Senate.--Mr. Hale moved the adjournment to-day be until Monday.

Mr. Powell's resolution to refer the secession portion of the President's Message to a special committee of thirteen was carried.--The committee will be appointed Monday.
The same committee is to inquire into the expediency of further legislation to protect the Federal property, and also of the expediency of amending the Constitution, to insure protection for property in States and Territories.
Mr. Latham introduced an inquiry to carry the whole California daily letter mail by Pony Express.
Adjourned at 12 ¼ o'clock.

House.--Mr. Morris, of Ill., gave notice that on Monday he should call up the resolution offered a few days since, looking to the perpetuity of the Union, and would ask a suspension of the rules for that purpose.
Mr. Vallandigham, from the special committee appointed last session, on the Senate bill abolishing the franking privilege, made a report proposing several amendments to it.--Ordered to be pirated.
On motion of Mr. Phelps, of Mo., it was ordered that when the House adjourn to-day, it be until Monday.
Mr. Cobb, of Ala., from the Committee on Public Lands, reported a bill, in the shape of a substitute, to construe the word "minimum" in designating the price of public lands.
Mr. Stevens, of Pa., moved the bill be tabled.

The Speaker appointed the following to constitute the committee of one from each State on the secession portion of the Message: Corwin, of Ohio; Millson, of Va.; , of Mass.; Winslow, of N. C.; Humphrey, of N. Y.; Boyce, of S. C.; Campbell, of Pa.; Love, of Ga.; Terry, of Ct.; Davis, of Md.; Robinson, of R. I.; Whitley, of Del.; Tappan, of N. H.; Stration, of N. J.; Bristow, of Ky.; Morrill, of Vt.; Nelson, of Tenn.; Dunn, of ; Taylor, of La.; Davis, of Miss.; Kellogg, of Ill.; Houston, of Ala.; Morse, of Me.; Mich.; Hawkins, of Fla.; Hamilton, of Tex.; Washburne, of Wis.; Curtis, of Iowa; Burch, of Cal.; Windom, of Min., and Stout, of Oregon.

Mr. Hawkins, of Fla. asked to be excused from serving on the committee.
He had been informed that if he refused without being formally excused, he would be reprimanded by the House, but his main reason for making the request was that he did not believe in the appointment of committees for Union-saving purposes now, as he had believed heretofore.
The time for compromise had passed.
John Cochrane, of New York, strongly appealed to Hawkins to withdraw his request.--His appeal was eloquent and patriotic, and drew applause from the galleries.

Mr. Garnett, of Va., promptly rebuked this outside manifestation of applause, whereupon the galleries hissed.
Mr. G. said those hissing were disgraceful blackguards, and he hoped the Chair would maintain order.
Quiet was restored.
Mr. Cochrane also condemned hissing or applause, and said if the American Congress is to fall let it fall with its robes of order decently wrapped around it.
Mr. Hawkins said his actions were the result of twenty years reflection.

Mr. Crawford, of Georgia, wanted to see if the House would force Hawkins to serve.
He hoped other Southern members would also ask to be excused.
Without taking a vote on Hawkins' request, the House adjourned until Monday, the Southerners voting against adjournment.
No doubt a large portion of the Southern members will ask to be excused from serving on the committee.

div3.head: From Washington.
div3.p:
Washington, Dec. 6. --The President to-day replied to the resolution of last session relative to the slave trade.
It appears that the African squadron has been maintained in the last twelve years at an annual excess over ordinary naval expenses of $380,000, and the excess of the present year, in consequence of the employment of steamers, will be $800,000.--Not withstanding this expenditure, the British Government has frequently complained of the inefficiency of our efforts, until at last the President has officially informed England that we don't want any more suggestions on the subject, as we consider ourselves abundantly able to regulate our own affairs.

Today, the Speaker's warrants for the pay of members of the House were refused at the Treasury for want of funds.
They will be formally protested to-morrow.
About $200,000 only has been paid to members since the session commenced.

There is a strong resolution on the part of the South not to yield to any proposed compromise, and the antagonism to the North daily increases.
It is improbable that any public business will be transacted until the secession question is settled.

div3.head:
Further by the Canadian.
Portland, Dec. 5.
div3.p: --The following are the chief items of interest embraced in the advices per steamer Canadian:

The report at London of the Emperor Napoleon having arrived privately, proved a hoax.
The railroad station was besieged by an anxious crowd to view the distinguished sovereign, but he did not appear.
The London Times hopes for an early reduction of the Bank rates of discount,
France.
Count Morney is going to Rome on a special mission, with an autograph letter from the Emperor.
It is stated that Count Walewski will succeed Count Persigny in the London Embassy.
Italy.

There is no new movements of interest.
The clergy in the Neapolitan provinces were engaged in paying their homage to Victor Emmanuel.
The Archbishop of Naples was about to return to his See.
The rumors of a new Sardinian loan were contradicted.
The Dowager Queen of Naples, with the young Princess, had arrived at Rome.
The French were about to occupy Terracina.

The siege of Gaeta continued.
The Piedmontese bombarded the suburbs on the 12th.

The further resistance of the Bourbon troops had been paralyzed by the insubordination of their chief.
Confusion was prevailing.
It was believed that the complete evacuation of Gueta had been resolved on.
A dispatch from Naples says that the ex-King had burst a blood vessel.
It was stated that negotiations for the cession of Venetia had been commenced.
The Empress Eugenia returns to France on the 10th of December.
The Brazilian corvette Donna Isabel was wrecked on the coast of Barbary, and 100 seamen and 23 officers lost.

div3.head: Important from New Orleans.
div3.p: New Orleans, Dec. 4. --There is no improvement in affairs here; but, on the contrary, matters are worse — business, in a word, is almost at a dead-lock, while quite a number of suspensions have taken place from the in ability of the parties to obtain relief, and the heavy fall in produce, particularly in cotton.
It is the impression of many here that the light receipts of cotton is because of the planters holding it back rather than accept of the low rates now current.
Operations in Exchange of all descriptions are small, and quotations very unsettled.--Money still goes hard, and at all sorts of rates.
The distrust of the future that exists is almost without a parallel, and it is feared the worst is yet to come.

div3.head: A Convention of the citizens of Texas.
div3.p: New Orleans, Dec. 4. --The citizens of Texas have been urged, in a circular letter, signed by a number of public gentlemen, to elect delegates to a State Convention on the 8th of January.
It is said that the Convention will assemble at the capital of the State on the fourth Monday of the same month.
The movement appears to meet with popular sanction.

div3.head: Northern Canal Navigation.
div3.p: Aleany, Dec. 5. --The weather has moderated, and there is but little ice in the Canal basins.

St. Cathabines, C. W., Dec. 4.--The Wel land Canal is almost impassable, from the snow which fell yesterday, and the ice which made last night.
Navigation will probably be stopped to- night.

div3.head: Herace Greeley Sued for Libel.
div3.p: Oswego, N. Y., Dec. 5.--Hon, D. C. Little-john has commenced a prosecution against Horace Greeley, of the New York Tribune, for alleged libels uttered pending the late election.

div3.head: Official vote of Missouri.
div3.p:
St. Louis, Dec. 5. --The official vote of Missouri has been announced.
It stands as follows.
For Douglas, 58,801; Rell, 58,372; Breckinridge, 31,317; Lincoln, 17,028.

div3.head: Newfoundland Legislature.
div3.p:
St. Johns, N. F., Dec. 4.--The Legislature met to-day.
The Governor's speech stated that the House was called to consider the destitution prevailing in the country in consequence of the short seal and cod fishery.--It condemned the system of giving relief indiscriminately, without any equivalent, and alluded to the irregularities of the Galway steamers, to the decrease of revenue, and the injustice of indirectly taxing many to benefit a few. It recommended to the Ministers to greater economy; it regretted that, the Commissioners not having completed their labors the terms of an adjustment with the French, relative to the fishing privileges, could not be published, although they were mainly agreed on.

div3.head: The Virginia Electoral vote.
div3.p:
Norfolk, Dec. 6. --Mr. W. Lamb, the Elector on the Breckinridge Democratic ticket, did not resign his seat in the Electoral College, as reported.
The resignation of the Breckinridge Electors is "generally condemned among Democrats."

div3.head: New York Finances.
div3.p:
New York, Dec. 6. --Money outside the Bank is dearer.
There is a continued shipment of specie to the South.
About $1,000,000 had been shipped Saturday.

div4.p:
--Flour dull — Howard Street and Ohio $5. Wheat dull and generally unchanged.
Corn dull and heavy — new white and yellow 49 @50 Provisions dull and quotations nominal.
Coffee declined ¼ @¾--Rio 13 ¼. Whiskey cull at 18 ½.

New York, Dec. 6. --There was a general decline in the stock market to-day of 4 per cent. Cotton — Uplands Middling 9 ¾@10 Flour 10 cts, lower — Southern $465@515.
Wheat 3@4 cents lower.
Corn 2 @3 cts, lower — closing at 60@61 for mixed.
Beef dull at $8.50@8.70.
Pork steady — mess $16.62@16.75 --chielly at the latter figure; prime $10@10.75.
Lard firm at 10@10 . Whiskey dull at 18.
Sugar is heavy — Orleans 4 ¾@6.
Molasses unchanged — Orleans 30@33 ½.
Turpentine heavy at 33@35.
Rosin heavy.
Rice dull at 3 ¾@3 ¾.
Stocks — New York Centrals 70 7/8; Va. 6's 76.
Sales yesterday of $9,000 Va. 6's at 79.

div3.head: Co-partnership.
div3.p:
--The subscribers have this day entered into a co-partnership, (under the style of Bosher & Wooddy.) for the purpose of conducting a Wholesale and Retail Grocery and Commission business, at the old stand of Wilson & Bosher, corner Main and 17th streets, where they will keep always on hand a well-selected stock of Family and Jobbing Groceries, to which they call the attention of their friends and the public.
They hope by strict attention to business to merit a share of public patronage.
Solicit consignments of all kinds of Country Produce, to the sale of which particular attention will be given.
Charles M. Bosher,
T. C. Wooddy,
(Late with Messrs. Perkins & Co.)

A Card.--Thankful for past favors.
I take this method of returning thanks to my friends and the public for the very liberal patronage extended to me for the last year, and most respectfully solicit a continuance of the same for the new concern of Bosher & Wooddy.
no 26--ts Charles M. Bosher.

div3.head: Notice
div3.p: --to the Creditors of Daniel Hagerty and of Hagerty & Starke. --Daniel Hagerty having assumed, by contract, the payment of the debts of the late firm of Hagerty & Starke, and being entitled, under the same contract, to all the assets of the late concern, including debts due it, and said Hagerty having, by deed dated the 21st November, 1860, recorded on the same day in the Clerk's Office of the Hustings Court for the city of Richmond, conveyed his stock of goods, and all his property and assets of every description, real and personal, to the undersigned, in trust, for the benefit of his creditors and the creditors of Hagerty & Starke, according to certain classes therein arranged; and said deed also providing, among other things, that no creditor shall be entitled to any benefit there from unless he assents to the terms of the said deed by signing the same within thirty days from its date--

Notice is hereby given to all persons indebted to the said Hagerty, or to the said firm, to settle immediately with the undersigned, and to persons having claims under the terms of said deed, to present the same.
And notice is also given that said deed will remain in the Clerk's Office of the Court of Hustings the prescribed time, to be signed by such creditors as are willing to accept the terms of the same.
V. Bargamin,
no 24--ts Trustee.

div3.head:
Planting Machines and steam
Engines
made upon Southern soil.
div3.p: the Union Manufacturing Co.,

Are now ready to furnish the celebrated Woodworth Planing Machines, which require no other recommendation than their already established reputation; and also Stationary steam Engines, of from 25 to 100 horse power, which they will build at a less price per horse power than they can be furnished by any Northern establishment.

These Machines are built under the personal supervision of John H. Lester, Esq., formerly of Brooklyn, N. Y., who, as a manufacturer, is well and widely known, and they are warranted to give satisfaction.
Office, 231 Main street.
Richmond, Virginia.
Send for a Descriptive Pamphlet no 23--ts.

div3.head: Important to Gas Consumers.
div3.p: Chas. H. Langley,
Gas Fitter, Tinner and Coppersmith,
Would inform the public that he is sole agent for the sale of
Hawley's Improved Cylinder Gas
Burners,

and is prepared to put them up at the shortest notice, and on the most reasonable terms.
The advantages of these Burners are: To prevent blowing and waste of gas, to give a more clear and uniform light, to regulate the quantity consumed with the full head turned on to any desired amount, and thus to save at least twenty-five per cent, over the ordinary Burners.

Mr. J. F. Brown, in charge of the Washington City Gas Works, has certified that they are unhesitatingly the best Burners he has seen during his connection of twelve years with those works; and the Superintendent of the Richmond Gas Works asserts that he has tried them, and that they save at least twenty per cent, over other Burners.

Thankful for past favors, the subscriber invites orders for all work in his line, feeling assured that he can give entire satisfaction as to quality and price.
Chas. H. Langley.
oc 4--ts 13th st., between Main and Cary

div3.head: Office of City Gas Works.
div3.p: I have Tested Mr. P. Fontain's Regulator on the Proof Metre, at the City Gas Works, and certify that they will save from thirty to forty per cent of Gas to the consumers.
John J. Fry, Sup't
After a trial on Proof Metre a net save of 50 ft, in five hours, with four burners, was made.
The above-named Regulators and Gas Purifiers can be obtained of Jos. Delarue, he having bought the right of Mr. P. Fontain for Richmond and Petersburg, Va.

table.head: Price of Gas Regulators and Purifier attached:

div3.p: For any orders or information, apply to
Jos. Delarue, 6th street,
no 22--1m Between Broad and Grace.

div3.head: Commissioner's Office.
div3.p: to the Creditors of the Estate of Lucy Coleman, Dec'd, and all others Concerned. --You are hereby notified that at the request of Mr. George A. Pearce, executor of the said Lucy Coleman, dec'd, I have appointed the 8th day of December next, at my office, for receiving proof of debts or demands against the said decedent or her estate, at which time and place you are required to attend.
Given under my hand, as Commissioner in Chancery of the County Court of Henrico County, the day and year first aforesaid.
no 29--td J. H. Sands.

div3.head: School of Design of the Virginia Mechanics' Institute.
div3.p:
--The above School will be opened in the basement of the Mechanics' Institute building, on Monday, November 19th, at 7 P. M., and on each Monday Wednesday and Friday succeeding, until the 1st of May, 1861. Besides Mechanical and Geometrical Drawing, the scholars can obtain instructions in Mathematics.
Trigonometry and Surveying, if desired.
For terms, apply to Mr. O. Heinrich, who will be in the school-room on the evenings of Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday of this week, or to the Committee.
T. H. Wynne,
L. L. Montague,
no 12--1m Jas. Kersey.

div3.head: Beautiful and Central Building Lots, Corner Broad and Capitol and 10th sts., for Rent or sale
div3.p:
--These building lots, fronting 54 feet on Capitol and Broad streets respectively, and 140 feet on 10th street, are, for private or public purposes, unequalled by any other in the city.
Surrounded by streets on three sides, and fronting the Capitol Square, they present rare attractions.
They will be rented on liberal terms or sold on a long credit.
no 19--ts J. B. Watkins, 159 Main st.

div3.head: U. S. M. Steamship Jamestown --for New York via Norfolk.
div3.p: --The Jamestown, Captain Thomas Skinner, will leave here at 4 o'clock P. M. Friday, the 7th inst.
Passengers are requested to be on board in due time.
Passage to New York, meals and state-room included, $10. Steerage passage only $5.
Passage to Norfolk same as by the river boats.

Freight received to-day.
Thursday, and up to the hour of 11 o'clock A. M., Friday.
Consignees are requested to send for their goods to
Tickets and berths secured at our office, or on board the ship.
Freight for Boston taken at moderate rates and forwarded with dispatch.
Ludlam & Watson.
N. B.--There will be no steamer on Saturday.
de 6--2t L.& W.

div3.head: Notice to Shippers and others.
div3.p:
--The Yorktown has been withdrawn from the line for the present.
The Jamestown, Capt. Skinner, and the Roanoke, Capt. Couch, will continue their trips between this city and New York, touching at Norfolk each day.
Days of departure from New York, every Tuesday and Saturday, at 3 P. M. Days of departure from Richmond, every Tuesday and Friday, at 4 P. M.
de 6--ts Ludlam & Watson.

div3.head: Chickahominy and James River line — change of hour of departure.
div3.p: --On and after Saturday next, December 1st, 1860, the Steamer A. H. Schultz will, until further notice, leave her wharf at Rocketts for Windsor Shades, every Saturday and Wednesday Mornings at 6 ½ o'clock.
Returning, the Schultz will leave Windsor Shades every Monday and Thursday Mornings, at the same hour.
no 30--6t D. J. Hill, Master.

div3.head: Change of hour for Starting for Portsmouth and Norfolk.
div3.p: --The Steamer Glen Cove will, on and after Friday Morning next, 30th inst., leave her wharf at Rocketts regularly every Friday, Monday and Wednesday Mornings, at 6 ½ o'clock precisely, for the above places, and return each alternate day, (except Sunday,) leaving Norfolk at the same hour, 6 ½ o'clock, and touch at all of the regular landings on the river, going and returning.
no 27--ts R. O. Haskins.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--The steamer Curtis Peck will, after Wednesday next, the 28th inst, be taken off the line between this place and Norfolk, to undergo some repairs.
Due notice of the return will be given.
[no 27--ts] R. O. Haskins.

div3.head: Fall and Winter Arrangement.--three Times a week, between Richmond and New York
div3.p: --only $10, Passage, State Room and Meals Included.--The U. S. Mail Steamships Yorktown, Jamestown, and Roanoke will leave Richmond for New York, as follows, stopping at Norfolk both going and returning, viz:
The Yorktown, Capt, Parrish, every Tuesday afternoon, at 4 o'clock.
The Jamestown, Capt Skinner, every Friday afternoon, at 4 o'clock.
The Roanoke, Capt, Couch, every Sunday afternoon, at 4 o'clock.
Returning from New York every Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday, at 3 P. M.
Steerage Passage to New York only $5.
Passage to Norfolk the same as by the river boats.

Excursion Tickets discontinued until the next season.
Ludlam & Watson,
oc 1--ts Opposite Steamers' Wharves.

div3.head: Notice.--Union Steamship line.
div3.p: --In consequence of some necessary repairs to the Steamship Virginia, she will be taken off the line until about the 20th inst, and notice will be given when she will resume her regular trips.

no 13--ts C. P. Cardozo.
Agent.

div3.head: For Liverpool.
div3.p: --Richmond and Liverpool Packet line.--The first ship of this line, the Virginia Dare, Captain J. M. Cole, will load at this port for Liverpool on or about the 20th of next month.
Shippers will bear in mind that, by special act of the Legislature, flour can be shipped on this ship, owned in Virginia, without inspection.
A large part of her freight is already engaged.--For balance of freight apply to.

div3.head: For sale.
div3.p:
--I have seven A No. 1 Riding and Driving Horses, some of them very stylish and fast.
I would like to sell two of them.
Any person desiring to purchase, may take their choice from the lot. Also, two new Drays, light and strong, all of which I propose to sell on accommodating terms.
They may be seen at my Stables, on the Dock, between 19 and 20th streets.
de 6--1m Edmond Bossieux.

div3.p:
--A Riding Horse, of fine action and perfectly gentle.
Apply to Jas. Hardin, or Mr. Hix, at the American Stables.

div3.p:
--A young, well-broke Horse — rides and works well-can be seen at our stable, in the rear of our ware-house.
[de 3--ts] Kent, Paine& Co.

div3.head: For sale.
div3.p:
--A fine, thoroughbred, Grey Horse, raised by Major Doswell, who will give his pedigree to any one wishing to purchase.
He was 5 years old last June, and is about 16 hands high; is a remarkably fine harness horse, and goes well under the saddle; can easily walk five miles an hour, and sound in every particular.
T. B. Grundy.
oc 13--ts 5th and Cary sts., or at Haxall's Mills.

div3.head: One fine Rosewood Piano for sale privately.
div3.p:
--The subscriber offers at private sale, for a few days only, one very handsome, round corner, seven octave, Rosewood Piano, made in this city.
This is an instrument of superior tone and finish, and warranted by the manufacturer for one year.
It will be sold low to any person making an early application.
[no 15--ts] J. H. Digges.

div3.head: Richmond-made Pianos for sale below Northern prices.
div3.p: The subscriber has on hand three new very superior 7 octave Pianos, which he warrants to be equal, if not superior, to any instrument of the same quality from Northern manufactories.

He also offers his services to the public as Tuner and Repairer of Pianos, at reasonable rates.
Conrad Freimann.
South side Broad st., between 2d and 3d.

div3.head: A Card.
div3.p:
--to the Ladies and Gentlemen of Richmond and its Vicinity.--Miss Rebecca Semon would respectfully inform the ladies and gentlemen that she has just received her stock of Fall and Winter Patterns, comprising the Zouave Jackets, for ladies; Japanese walking-Coat and Cape, for little boys; Garrick Coat, Spanish Dress, Zouave Coat Lennet Coat and Dress Jacket, and a number of Apron Patterns for little boys.
Also, the Lulu and Victoria Walking Dress, for little girls; Zouave and Cleopatra Aprons, and a number of Dress Sleeve Patterns.

Miss Semon is now ready to Braid and Embroider the Zouave Jackets, for ladies and children.
Also, Ladies' and Children's Flannels; Sacks and Wrappings for Infants; Suits Embroidered for little boys.
Also, Pinking, Drawing and Stamping done at the shortest notice, in her room, at her father's residence, 2 doors below St. Charles Hotel.
[no 15--1m] Miss Rebecca Semon.

div3.head: Artificial Teeth.
div3.p:
--the Cheoplastic and Vulcanite Process.--G. W. Jones, Dentist, having the right for the above mode of making Teeth, and being satisfied of its absolute superiority over all other methods, can with confidence commend it to those desiring full or partial sets of teeth, and especially such as may be dissatisfied with those they are now using.
The perfect adaptation of the plate to the mouth, and the suction thereby secured, enables him to insert one or more teeth without clasps. This method having been adopted by those standing highest in the profession, North and South, testimonials will be given and specimens exhibited to those wishing to see them.
Sets of Teeth on gold or any other plate, will of course, be made for those preferring them Filling, Cleansing, Extracting, and all other operations gently and thoroughly performed.
Teeth extracted by Electricity, without pain.

Office on Main street, opposite Corinthian Hall.
de 1--1y
