div3.p: --500 lbs, of the finest Venison you ever saw, for sale by
Wm. G. Dandridge, No. 105 Broad st.

div3.head: Future days.
div3.p: By Jas. M. Tayler & Sen, Auct's.

Commissioners' sale of valuable House and Lot, on the South side of Cary, between 7TH and 8TH streets.--As Commissioners of the Circuit Court of the City of Richmond, appointed by a decree entered on the 26th of November, 1860, in the cause of Foster vs. Foster et al, we shall sell at public auction, on the premises, on Thursday, the 20th of December, 1860, at 4 o'clock P. M. (if fair; if not, the next fair day,) a valuable House and Lot, fronting 34 feet on the south side of Cary street, between 7th and 8th, running back 164 feet, and now occupied by M. Mayer as a clothing store.
Terms.--One-third cash; one-third on a credit of 12 months, and the residue on a credit of 18 months, for negotiable notes, interest added, and title retained until the further order of the Court.
Chastain White, Comr's.
James B. Foster, Comr's.
James M. Taylor & Son, Aucts. de 7

div3.head: Valuable Lot and Cottage residence at Auction.
div3.p:
--We will sell at public auction, upon the premises, on Tuesday, the 11th, day of December, 1860, commencing at 4 o'clock P. M., that valuable Lot with a comfortable Cottage Building thereon, situated on the east line of 2d, between Jackson and Duval streets, for many years occupied by Miss Carolina Kerr, and is now occupied by a good tenant at $200 per annum.
The Lot fronts 40 feet on 2d street, and extends back within parallel lines 130 feet to an alley 27 feet wide.
The premises have received such repairs, painting, &c., as to render it a desirable residence for a moderate-sized family.
Terms.--One fifth cash; the balance at 6, 12, 18 and 24 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a deed of trust.
de 7 Jas. M. Taylor & Son, Auct'rs.

div3.head: By Goddin & apperson, Auct's.
div3.p:
Commissioner's sale of Lots and Houses on Valley and Concord sts., Richmond — Under a decree of the Circuit Court of Richmond city, pronounced on the 29th day of November, 1860, in the suit of Dennis and wife vs. McKenny and als, therein pending, the undersigned, Commission therein appointed, will proceed to sell at public auction, on the premises, on Saturday, the 22d day of Dec, 1860, (if fair; if not, the first fair day thereafter,) beginning at 4 o'clock. P. M., the real estate in said decree referred to, consisting of a lot of ground fronting 30 feet 6 inches on Valley street, opposite the residence of John Priddy.
Esq, with the dwelling-house and other improvements thereon.
Also, a lot of ground immediately in rear of the above, fronting 30 feet 6 inches on Concord st., with the two framed tenements and other improvements to said lot belonging.

Terms.--One-fourth cash; the balance upon a credit of 6, 12 and 18 months, interest added from day of sale, the purchase or purchasers to give negotiable notes for the deferred payments, and the title to be retained until all the purchase money be paid, and a conveyance directed by the Court,
R. R. Howison, Com'r.
Sale by Goddin & Apperson, Aucts. de 7

div3.head: By E. B. Cook, Auct'r.
div3.p:
Horses, Mules, Buggies, Wagon, Cows, &c., at Auction.--On Saturday, 9th inst, at 10 o'clock. I will sell at the lot on Council Chamber Hill, several Harness and Saddle Horses, amongst which is a large bay, 5 years old, well broke, perfectly gentle, said to be quite fast; also, a sprightly filly, 3 years old, well broke in single or double harness.
One pair large well broke Mules, 3 years old, in most excellent order, sold for no fault, the owner being about removing from the country to the city.
Also — A very superior Top-Buggy, with harness, cost $250 has been used a very short time; 1 no-top Buggy and harness, in good order; 1 large Wagon, suitable for a street or country wagon.
The Filly, pair of Mules and Wagon will be sold upon accommodating terms.
de 7 E. B. Cook, Auct'r,

div3.head: By Alex, Nott, Auct'r.
div3.p: Furniture, Dry Goods, Groceries, &c.--Will be sold at auction, at my store, corner of Main and 15th sts, on Saturday Morning, the 8th day of December, commencing at 10 o'clock, a general assortment of new and second-hand Furniture, Stoves, &c.
Dry Goods.--Hoop Skirts, Net Shirts, Drawers, Jackets, Coats, Pants, Caps, Hosiery, Shoes, Galters. &c.
Groceries.--Brandy, Whiskey, Tobacco, Crockery, Cigars, Champagne, &c.
de 7 Alex. Nott, Auct.

div3.head: By Thomas W. Keesee, Auct'r.
div3.p: [Office corner of 12th and Cary streets.]

Horses, Mules, Cows and Calves, Buggy and Wagon, for sale at Auction. --Will be sold on Saturday morning, Dec, 8th, commencing at 10 o'clock, at the Horse Auction Lot, on Council Chamber Hill, 6 good Saddle and Harness Horses; 4 good work Mules; 2 good Milch Cows and Calves; one Buggy and Harness; one second-hand Spring Wagon.
[de 7] Thos. W. Keesee, Auct'r.

div3.head: By Richard Cauthorn, Auct.
div3.p: Groceries, Liquors, &c., at Auction.--I will sell at my store, on Monday, the 10th inst., commencing at 10 o'clock, 8 hhds. Shoulders; 2 do, Hams; 10 bbls. Whiskey; 10 do. Herrings; Coffee; Sugar; Salt; Tobacco; Crockery and Tin ware; Soap, Candles, &c.

Also — A lot of second hand Furniture, Feather Beds.
Stoves, &c., &c.
de 7 R. Cauthorn, Auct'r.

div3.head: By J. H. Digges, Auct'r.
div3.p: Auction--Horses, Mules. &c., &c.--Will be sold on Saturday, the 8th inst., commencing at 10 o'clock at the Horse Lot, on Council Chamber Hill, several Saddle and Work Horses; several good Work Mules; 1 Dray and Harness; 1 Buggy and Harness; 2 good Carts.
Additional--One fine Harness and Saddle Horse, 5 years old, on a credit of 90 days.
de 7 J. H. Digges, Auct.

div3.head: Commissioner's sale of valuable Farm of 306 acres, near short Pump, in the County of Henrico.
div3.p:
--As Commissioner, acting under a decree of the Circuit Court of the County of Henrico, entered on the 3d day of November, 1860, in the suit of Duval et als vs. Duval et als, I shall, on the 28th day of December, 1860, at 12 o'clock of that day, on the premises sell at public auction, to the highest bidder, a valuable Farm, now in the occupancy of T. C. Leake, Esq., containing 306 acres more or less, adjoining the lands of Wm. McGruder, Cottrell, and others, about twelve miles west of Richmond, near Short Pump, in the county of Henrico.
About 100 acres of the land is cleared and in a good state of cultivation; the balance is in wood and timber.
The place has on it a good Framed Dwelling with five rooms, and all necessary out-house, in good order; also, a good Peach and Apple Orchard.
The soil is well adapted to the growth of the usual crops.

Terms.--One-third will be required in cash, and the balance in two equal instalments, payable respectively in 12 and 18 months, with interest from the day of sale, the purchaser to execute his bonds for the deferred payments, and the title to be retained-until the further order of the Court.
de 7--dtd Jno. H. Holman, Com'r.

div3.head: Commissioner's sale of valuable property in Henrico County.
div3.p:
As Commissioner of the County Court of Henrico, appointed by a decree entered Nov, 5th, 1860. I shall sell at public auction, on the premises on Tuesday, Dec. 18th, 1860, (if fair; if not, the next fair day,) a tract of land of which Wm. C. Roundtree, dec'd, died seized, situated about 9 miles above Richmond, on the old Richmond Turnpike, containing about 41 ¾ acres upon which there is a small house and out-buildings.
Most of the tract is covered with very heavy and valuable oak, chestnut and other timber.
Terms.--One-third cash; balance in one and two years, for bonds, interest added; title retained, or secured by deed of trust.
Samuel T. Bayly.
de 7--19t Special Commissioner.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--Will be sold, in front of Henrico County Court-House, on the 1st day of January Court, 1861, for cash, a Negro Woman, named Jane Cousins.
The said woman is a free negro, convicted by the County Court of Henrico County, at its present term (December) of grand larceny, and ordered to be sold into absolute slavery, according to law. The above sale will take place at 12 o'clock M.
de 7--tds John A. Hutcheson, S. H. C.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--Will be sold at the Quarry on the farm of Jno. A. Hutcheson, on James River Canal, three and a half miles above the city of Richmond, on Wednesday, the 12th day of December, 1860, at 12 o'clock M., all the fixtures used at said Quarry, consisting of two Derricks.
Tackle, Barrows, &c., &c., to satisfy an execution in my hands in favor of Jacob Woodson vs. Wm. Thom and M. Giannini.
de 7--td Jno. A. Hutcheson, S. H. C.

div3.head: Commissioner's sale of about 85 acres of land, about 12 miles below Richmond, at public Auction.
div3.p: --On Monday, the 17th day of December, 1860, at 11 o'clock A. M., I will sell at public auction, to the highest bidder, the Tract of land of which John J. Eppes died possessed, situated about 12 miles below Richmond, near Willis' meeting- house and adjoining the lands of James W. Binford, John Whitlock's estate and others, and supposed to contain about 85 acres.

Terms.--One third cash; the balance in two equal instalments of 9 and 18 months, bearing interest from date of sale, the purchaser executing his bond for the deferred payments, and title retained until ordered by Court.
de 6--tds Geo. D. Pleasants, Com'r.

div3.head: Administrator's sale of Personal
div3.p: property, at Auction.--On Monday, the 17th day of December, (immediately after the sale of the land,) I shall proceed to sell to the highest bidder, all of the Personal Estate of John J. Eppes, dec'd, consisting of Horses, Cows, crop of Corn, Fodder, Shucks Household and Kitchen Furniture, &c.
Terms.--All sums under $20, cash; that amount and over, 6 months credit will be given, the purchaser executing bonds, with good security.
All persons having claims against the estate of John J. Eppes, dec'd, will please present them to me, and those who are indebted to the said estate will please make prompt payment to me.
Geo. D. Pleasants.
de 6--tds Adm'r of John J. Eppes, dec'd.

div3.head: Richmond Type Foundry, located in the law Building,
div3.p:
The proprietors of the above establishment beg leave to say that they are prepared to execute any orders for Newspaper, Book or Job Printing Offices, and are now manufacturing, on the spot, a new dress for the Richmond Dispatch.
In soliciting the patronage of the South we guarantee to furnish as good an article as can be had North, and at New York prices.
We have extensive business connections with nearly all the type foundries in the United States, and are, therefore, enabled to furnish Type of other manufacturers when required.

We desire every newspaper in the South to copy this advertisement for one month sending us one copy of the paper, and they will receive their pay by purchasing of us five times the amount of their bill for such advertisement.
Walker & Pelouze.

no 29--1m Richmond.
Va.

div3.head: Manchester Scale Works.
div3.p:
--We have on hand from the above factory.
Platform Scales, weighing from 400 to 2000 lbs.--Also, Counter Scales of every variety, and is agents for the manufacturers are prepared to take orders for railroad track, depot and warehouse Scales, &c., which for neatness, durability and accuracy cannot be surpassed.
Van-Lew, Taylor & Co.,
ja 10>--1y No, 74 Main street,

div3.head: Future days.
div3.p:
Commissioners' sale of Real Estate in the Town of Fulton, near to Rocketts.--As Commissioners of the Circuit Court of Henrico, appointed by a decree entered on the 1st November, 1860 in the case of Enroughty and wife against Bergman, &c., we shall sell at public auction, on the premises, on Monday, the 10th December, 1860, at 3 ½ o'clock P. M., (if fair; if not, the first fair day,) the real estate located as above of which the late Fred. Bergman died seized, and now occupied by his widow.
There are several beautiful building lots, and an excellent new Brick Tenement, used as a Store and Dwelling, and considered an excellent stand for business.

Terms.--Enough in cash to defray the expenses of sale and costs of suit; balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, interest added, satisfactorily endorsed, and title retained till the further order of the Court.
P. H. Aylett. Comr's.
Henry G. Cannon, Comr's.
no 27 Johnson H. Sands, Comr's.

div3.head: Trustee's sale of House and Lot on Duval street.
div3.p: --Under the provision of a trust deed executed by L. Q. Landrum and wife, dated April 1st, 1859, to the late Richard J. Blunt, to secure a debt of $350, with interest, I shall proceed to sell, on the premises, on Tuesday, 11th December, 1860, at 4 o'clock P. M., that land, with a Building thereon, lying on the south side of Duval street, nearly opposite the Duval street Church, and fronting 21 feet on said Duval street. The lot is part of No, 11, in Duval & Pleasants Plan.

Terms.--Cash, to satisfy expenses of sale and debt secured by trust deed; for the balance, on a credit of six months, purchaser executing his negotiable note, interest added, and title retained until credit instalment is paid.
John A. Hutcheson,
Sheriff of Henrico county, and as such Administrator of Richard J. Blunt.
Sale by Goddin & Apperson, Aucts. de 1

div3.head: Two most valuable Building Lots, on the east side of 3d between Franklin and Main streets, for sale at Auction.
div3.p: --At the request of W. A. Robinson, Esq., we shall sell at public auction, on the premises, on Tuesday, the 11th December, 1860, at 4 o'clock P. M., a portion of that very valuable Lot, located as above, now in the occupancy of Rev. Dr. Minnigerode viz; A Lot fronting 45 feet on the east side of 3d street, north of the dwelling, running back 90 feet; also, a Lot fronting 68 feet on the east side of 3d street, south side of the dwelling, running back on the north side of Main street 90 feet to the residence of Dr. F. W. Hancock.
This is justly regarded as very valuable real estate: being not only in a most delightful neighborhood, but quite convenient to the business parts of the city.
Terms.--One-fourth cash; balance at 4, 8 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, interest added, secured by a trust deed or title retained.
de 5 Goddin & Apperson, Auct'rs.

div3.head: Trust sale of valuable Brick Dwelling, on the North side of Clay, between 2d and 3d streets.
div3.p:
--By virtue of a deed of trust from Richard Walsh and wife, bearing date the 16th day of December, 1857, recorded in Richmond Hustings Court, and by request of the beneficiary therein, the undersigned.
Trustee thereby appointed, will proceed to sell, at public auction, on the premises, on Friday, the 14th day of December, 1860, beginning at 4 o'clock P. M., (if fair; if not, the next fair day thereafter,) the property in said deed conveyed, consisting of a Lot of ground, fronting 33 feet on the north side of Clay street, between 2d and 3d, running back at right angles about 150 feet, to an alley 13 feet wide, with the large and handsome Brick Dwelling-House, and all other improvements to said lot belonging, it being the late residence of the said Richard Walsh.

Terms.--Cash as to the sum of $1,200; balance payable 1st day of December, 1861, with interest from day of sale, the purchaser giving a negotiable note for the deferred payment and interest, secured by lien on the property.
Henry Miller, Trustee.
Sale by Goddin & Apperson, Aucts. de 4

div3.head: Sale of Real Estate near Manchester.
div3.p:
--Will be sold on Saturday, the 15th day of December, 1860, at 3 ½ o'clock P. M., a Lot, in Snelling's Plan, near Manchester, fronting 60 feet on the south side of Wall street, running back 130 feet on Pocahontas street, with an unfinished building thereon.
Also, several Vacant Lots, near the above.

Terms.--One-fourth cash; balance at 3, 6 and 9 months, for negotiable notes, interest added and title retained.
Goddin & Apperson,
de 4 Auctioneers,

div3.head: By Ro. B. Lyne, Auct'r.
div3.p:
valuable Market Farm, five miles below Richmond, on the Charles City Road, containing 45 acres, for sale at public Auction.--At the request of Mr. Theodore Hoppe, I shall sell at public auction, on the 10th day of December, at the hour of 11 o'clock, upon the premises, (if fair; if not, the next fair day thereafter,) that valuable small Farm situated as described above, containing 45 acres, and adjoins the lands of Ro, Farrar and others, about half cleared; the balance woods.
The cleared land is well adapted to the growth of the usual crops, especially vegetables.--The improvements are sufficient for the accommodation of a moderate sized family.
There is a pump of excellent water in the yard.
The location is healthy and society good.

Immediately after the sale of the farm, will be sold all the Stock, Plantation Utensils, crop of Cron.
Fodder, &c.
Mr. Hoppe, living on the premises, will take pleasure in showing it to any one wishing to purchase.
Terms.--Made known on day of sale.
no 28--dtds Ro. B. Lyne, Auct.

div3.head: Executor's sale of a valuable
div3.p:
Farm in Henrico County, 12 miles below the City of Richmond, on the New Charles City Road, containing about 500 acres of land, together with the Stock of Horses, (several of which are young and very valuable,) Cows Hogs, Plantation Utensils, crops of Corn, Shucks, Fodder, Straw, &c., at Auction.--I will as the Executor of John Brackett, deceased, sell on Tuesday, the 18th of December, 1860 at his late residence, at the hour of 11 o'clock, (if fair; if not, the next fair day thereafter,) that valuable Farm upon which the said Brackett resided at the time of his death, situated as described above, containing about 500 acres of land, half cleared, a portion of which is meadow, very rich and productive.--The balance of the land is well set in pine and oak. The improvements consist of a framed dwelling, containing 7 or 8 rooms; kitchen, negro quarters, barn, stable, carriage-house, &c. The location is considered very healthy and society good, convenient to churches and mills.
And immediately after the sale of the Farm, will be sold the stock of Horses, Cows, Hors, Plantation Utensils, a Carriage and Harness, (nearly new,) House-hold and Kitchen Furniture, crops of Corn, Shucks, Fodder.
Straw, &c.

Terms of Sale.--For the land, one-third cash; balance upon a credit of one, two and three years to bear interest from day of sale, which is to be paid semi- annually.
For personal property, all sums of twenty dollars and under, cash; sums over twenty dollars, six months credit, for approved paper, to be given before property is delivered.
William Brackett.
Ex'or of John Brackett, deceased.
Sale conducted by Ro. B. Lyne, Auct [no 15--td]

div3.head: By E. B. Cook, Auc'r.
div3.p: large assortment of Ladies' Furs at Auction.--On , Wednesday, 12th inst., at 12 o'clock, I will sell at my store, 70 Main street, a choice invoice of Ladies' Furs, embracing--
Stone Martin Victorines.
Stone Martin Cuffs.
American Sable Victorines.
American Sable Cuffs.
Fine Black Lynx Victorines.
Fine Black Lynx Cuffs,
Siberian Squirrel Victorines and Cuffs
Russian Fitch Victorines and Cuffs
Mountain Martin Victorines and Cuffs
French Genett Victorines and Cuffs.
--Also,--
Ladies' and Children's Muffs, from low priced to very fine.

The goods will be open the day before the sale at which time the ladies are respectfully invited to call and examine.
E. B. Cook.
de 5 Auctioneer.

div3.head: Trustee's sale of Household and Kitchen Furniture, at Auction.
div3.p:
--By virtue of a deed of trust from Richard Walsh, dated the 9th day of February, 1860, recorded in Richmond Hustings Court, the under signed.
Trustee therein appointed, will proceed to sell at public auction, on Monday, 17th inst., at 10 o'clock, at the late residence of the said Richard Walsh, on the north side of Clay street, between 2d and 3d streets, the Personal property in said deed conveyed consisting of a lot of Household and Kitchen Furniture embracing--
Sofas, Tables, Chairs, Carpets.
Mirrors. Bedsteads, Beds and Bedding,
China, Glassware, Crockery,
and many other articles of use and ornament.
Terms made known at sale.
R. R. Howison, Trustee.
Sale conducted by E. B. Cook, Auct'r. de 5

div3.head: By Jas. M. Taylor & Son, Auct's.
div3.p:
Trustee's sale of Thirty three acres of land on the Williamsburg Stage Road, in Henrico County.--By virtue of a deed of trust from Elvira C. Garrett, dated the 28th day of February, 1860, and of record in the Clerk's Office of Henrico County Court, (D. B. 74. P. 185.,) I shall, at the request of the beneficiary, proceed to sell upon the premises, on Friday, the 14th day of December, 1860, (if fair; if not, the next fair day thereafter.) commencing at 12 o'clock M., the property described in said deed, as follows; "All that certain piece or parcel of land lying and being in the county of Henrico, on the north side of the Williamsburg Stage Road, and containing thirty-three Acres, more or less, adjoining the lands of Samuel Bradley's children.
Polly Shum.
William F. Hord, and others, and being the same real estate conveyed to said Elvira C. Garrett by Charles Hagan trustee for Margaret Dobbins, and of hers, by deed bearing date 28th February, 1860, and recorded as above.

Terms--Enough in cash to defray the expenses of sale, and a bond for $200, with interest from December 1st, 1860 till paid; the remainder upon such terms as may be agreed upon on the day of sale.
John J. Fallen, Trustee,
Jas. M. Taylor & Son, Aucts. de 4

div3.head: Commissioners' sale of a very large and desirable Stock of Lumber, six Mules, Wagons, Lease,&c.
div3.p: --By virtue of a decree of the Circuit Court of the city of Richmond, in the case of Raglands vs. James C. McCarthy, the undersigned Commissioners therein appointed, will proceed to sell at public auction, on Monday, December 10, 1860, at 10 o'clock A. M., on the premises, all the large and valuable stock of Lumser, in the yard of J. C. McCarthy & Co., corner of Byrd and 6th sts., embracing the largest and most desirable stock of Lumber ever offered for sale in this city.

At the same time will be sold six Mules, two Wagons, one large Herring's fire proof safe Office Furniture, and all the other personal effects of J. C. McCarthy & Co, together with the unexpired Lease of the buildings and lumber yard, having two years to run from the 1st of January, 1831.

Terms.--Cash for all purchases amounting to $50 and under; over that sum, 60 days for satisfactorily endorsed negotiable notes, with interest added.
H. K. Ellyson, Com'rs.
G. W. Randolph Com'rs.
de 5--tds A. H. Sands, Com'rs.

div3.head:
This day.
by E. B. Ceek, Auct'r.
div3.p: A large assortment of entirely New Mahogany and Black Walnut Furniture, elegant Velvet Tapestry and Brussells Carpets, Negro Woman, &c, at Auction.--On Friday, the 7th inst, at 10 o'clock. I will sell at my store, a large and superior assortment of handsome Mahogany and Black Walnut Furniture, consisting of--
12 Mahogany Patti Bureaus.
6 Mahogany Marble-top Bureaus.
6 large, handsome Mahogany Sofas.
8 London, French and New York styles Mahogany Tete-A-Tetes.
8 Black Walnut Sofas and Divans.
2 very pretty Mahogany Secretaries and Book-cases.
--Also--
2 sets very handsome Oak Cottage Furniture, Marble-tops.
2 sets very handsome Drab Cottage Furniture, Marble-tops.

The above Furniture is entirely new and can be recommended, having been made to order for the Southern trade.
The attention of the trade and the public generally is requested.
at the same time, will be sold--
1 elegant Velvet Tapestry Carpet, 16 by 16.
1 elegant Velvet Tapestry Carpet 16 by 18.
1 elegant Brussells.Tapestry Carpet 17 by 18.

1 elegant Brussells.
Tapestry Carpet 13 by 16.

1 elegant Brussells.
Tapestry Carpet 15 by 16.
The above Carpets are of the very best Velvet and Brussells, entirely new, and worthy the attention of those in want of an elegant Carpet.
after which, will be sold--
A Negro Woman, about 43 years of age, a No. 1 Washer and Ironer, and a very good plain Cook.
Sale positive, Come and see.
de 6 E. B. Cook, Auct'r.

div3.head: Household Furniture at Auction.
div3.p:
--On Friday, 7th inst, at 10 o'clock. I will sell, at the residence on 17th street, opposite.
Toop's grocery, a general assortment of House-hold Furniture, embracing the usual variety.
de 6 E. B. Cook, Auct.

div3.head: High Constable's sale.
div3.p: --Will be sold, on Friday, the 7th day of December, 1860, at 10 o'clock A. M., at the High Constable's Office, a general assortment of Household and Kitchen Furniture, consisting of Bureaus, Wardrobes, Carpets, Tables, Chairs, Bedsteads, Feather Beds, Mirrors, Hair and Shuck Mattresses, Clocks, Washstand, Basing and Ewers; lot of Books, including one volumes of Milton's Complete Works.

Also--One bbl of superfine old family Whiskey, and one bbl, of Copal Varnish, and one fine, open-face, full jeweled.
M. J. Tobias Gold Lever Watch, to satisfy sundry distress warrants and executions in my hands.

Terms.--Cash.
F. Butler. H. C. C. R.
de 5--3t

div3.head: By J. H. Digges, Auct'r.
div3.p:
fine Gold and Silver Watches, Jewelry, Fancy Goods, &c.--Will be sold at auction, every night this week, at Auction Room 86 Main street. Also, a lot of Blankets.
Undershirts, Drawers, fine Table Cutlery, Plated Spoons, Forks, &c., &c. Sale will commence at 7 o'clock, P. M. J. H. Diggers, Auct.

D. F. Booth, Salesman.
oc 23--ts.

div3.head: Coke.
div3.p: --The prices of Carbon Hill Coke, until further notice, will be as follows
Lump Coke, $5.50 per load.
Stove Coke, $5 per load.
Hail Coke, $5 per load.
oc 29--ts Jno. J. Werth, Agent.

div3.head: Coal.--C. B. Lipscomb,
div3.p: (Office 14th st., opp Mayo's Warehouse,)
Dealer in Midlothian, Lump, Hail and Smith's Coal.

Also, Red and White Ash Anthracite Coal, sold by weight.
au 27--3m

div3.head: Oak and Pine Wood
div3.p: --Seasoned and under shelter, for sale at Coke Yards.
de 12--ts Jno. J. Werth. Ag't.

div3.head: The place
div3.p:
to buy cheap Goods is certainly at No, 25 Main street, where can be found Bosoms at 6.; Hoop Skirts at 25; Flannel at 16 2/3 and 20c; best Ladies' Bootees at $1 and $1.25; Plain and Figured Mouslaines at 12 ½c; Men's and Ladies' Collars at 6; Merinos at 30, and bargains in almost all kinds of Dry Goods.
Don't forget the place, at
Wertheimer & Lowenberg's.
de 1--1m No. 25 Main street.

div3.head: New Goods from the
div3.p: Crenshaw Woolen Mills,
Richmond.
Fancy Casimeres, all wool.
Ladies' Cloak Cloths.
Bed Blankets, &c.
For sale by Samuel M. Price & Co.
de 1--ts

div3.head: Window Shade Depot--
div3.p: 230 Broad street.

My stock of Window Shades being very large.
I am determined to run them off cheaper than ever.
The following is my list of prices,-- Dark Landscapes, 31 cents, worth 75; Plain Gold Shades. 75 cents, with fixtures complete; Gold with Centre, $1, worth at least $3; Gold and Velvet, $1.50, worth $4; beautiful Bouquets, 75 cents, cheap at $1.50; splendid Vase Shades, 90 cents, can't be bought elsewhere for $2; Gothic style.
Dry Landscapes.
Pleasure and Hunting Scenes, in endless variety; German, English and American Oil Cloths, all widths, very cheap; Table and Stand Covers; Hearth Rugs, very low and all wool; Carpeting only 50 cents, a great bargain; 150 large glit-framed Parlor Pictures, rich scenery, at the astonishing low price of $2, worth $6; also, a large line of Dry Goods, cheap for cash.
Call soon at the established cheap Dry Goods and Window Shade Store of M. Golden, 230 Broad street.

P. S.--I keep no traveling agents.
se 19--3t

div3.head: The greatest bargains in buying Dry Goods
div3.p:
is at No. 27 Main St.colors of Merinos, at 1s., cheap at 37 ½; plain and figured Mouslline de Laine at 1s.; 3,300 yards handsome striped, figured and plaid Valencia at 25 cts., selling elsewhere at 37 ½; fast-colored Prints at 8; Linen Handkerchiefs at 6, 8 and 12, &c.; Irish Linens from 25c, and upwards, at half their value; Ladies' and Gent's Shawls, astonishing low; Bed and Servants' Blankets, from 75c to $6, worth twice the money; Bleached and Bro. Shirtings and Sheetings; Kentucky Jeans; Satinets; Cassimeres; Sheeps' Grey; Tweeds; Linsey; Flannels, the cheapest in the city of Richmond; fine Cambric, Worked.
Striped, and 1,000 Ladies.
Collars, the richest worked, from 12 ½, 25, to $2, cheap at double that amount.
Carpetings I will sell at cost to close out. All in want of any Dry Goods will save 25 per cent, by calling without delay at No, 27 Main st. Joseph Strauss.

--Owing to the tightness of money matters, and the critical State of the country, we will offer our entire stock of goods at such reduced prices as to suit the most economical ones.
Tarlatans, 16 cents a yard; Cloaks, $4 and $5; Linen Cambric Hdkfs.
at 8, 10 and 12 cents--some very superior at 16 cents, admitted by every body to be worth 25 cents, Cambric Bands, 25 cents; Bonnet Velvets, $1.50; Ladies' White Cotton Hoge extra heavy, at 12 ½ cts. Rich Crochet Fringes at $1.50 and higher prices; Dress Trimmings a great reduction made; Head Dresses, Bleached Cottons, Black Silks and Corsets, at low prices, and so many other articles.
The ladies may rest assured that the goods must be sold at some prices, as the whole and entire stock will be closed out. So don't delay, but go to the right store, which is E. Goldsmit.
176 Broad street.

div3.head: Uncurrent money, received at par.
div3.p:
--North and South Carolina Bank notes, uncurrent Virginia money, notes of the Georgia, Alabama.
Tennessee, Louisiana, Kentucky and all other solvent Banks in the United States will be received at my Store, at their par value, without discount, for Dry Goods of every description, at prices reduced to suit the present hard times.
Purchasers who have not furnished themselves with their Fall and Winter Dry Goods, will find this a rare opportunity of doing so, on very favorable terms.
The whole of my valuable stock will be offered at prices Regardless of cost, for cash only.
Call soon at the Bargain Emporium of Alfred Moses,
63 Main street.

div3.head: Dry Goods at reduced prices Dry Goods at reduced prices
div3.p:
--To be prepared in the best manner possible for whatever may be the result of the present political excitement, we offer our entire stock of Goods at reduced prices.
The stock is large and better than it has ever been before at this season.
Carpets, Cloaks.
Dress Silks, Poplins, Ripps, Merinos, Mouselaines, Servants' Clothing of all kinds; in short, every variety of Dry Goods at very reduced prices.
Our customers may expect bargains in every style of Goods, as they must be sold before the close of the season.
Chiles & Chenery.

div3.head: At prime cost, for cash.--positively to close business — Store for Rent.
div3.p:
--With a view to raise money to meet our maturing obligations, and to discontinue the Dry Goods business, we offer our entire stock of Staple and Fancy Dry Goods at and under cost, for each, until the 10th day of December, when the whole stock will be offered at auction, and the sale continued from day to day, until sold.
The terms of the auction will be duly notified.
Until that time our friends who will give us a call, can get useful family goods at their own prices.
Chas. A. Gwatein.
8th and Main street, North side.
N. B.--The store is for rent.

div3.head: Robes at half price!
div3.p:
--Great sale of Dress Goods.--To make a clearing out of our entire stock of Fancy Dress Goods, shall offer rich Silk Rotes at half price, Cashmere and Valentia do., at half price; Mouselain and Poplin do., at half price; rich Printed and Plain Velours; Poplins.
Valentias and Merinos; striped and check Silks at 62 ½ and 75 cts.; Velvet and Cloth Cloaks; Southern-made Cassimere and Servants Clothing; All of which will be offered at such prices as to insure sales.
Cash purchasers expressly invited to examine at 97 Main street.
Christian & Lathrop.

div3.head: Grates, Fenders — fine Sets of Tongs, Shovels and Pokers
div3.p:
--I have for sale a large and elegant assortment of all kinds of Enamelled Grates, with Fenders; Summer Pieces of every style; handsome and plain sets of Shovels, Tongs, Pokers, Coal Scuttles, Cinder Shovels, Blower Stands, handsome stands for Shovels and Tong Brees and Iron Footmen, Fire-Brick Stabs and Jame.
All kinds of Church and Tavern Bells, Brees Brick Moulds, all kinds of Grates, Fenders, &c. made to order at the lowest Northern prices.
S. D. Denoon.
No. 295 Main street, between 8th and 9th.
se 13--3m West side.

div3.head: Executors' notice.
div3.p:
--All persons indebted to the estate of Mrs. Frances G. Taliaferro, of Hanover, are requested to make immediate payment.
Those having claims against her estate will present them, property authenticated, to the undersigned, or either of them.
Wm. O. Winston. Ex'rs.

no 3--3taw8w Geo. W. Cosby.
Ex'rs.

div3.head: Selling off.
div3.p:
--The stock of Planished, Japanned and Plain Tinware, Gas Fixtures, Stoves, &c. in the store of D. Hagerty, (late Hagerty & Starke,) No. 200 Main street, is offered for sale at cost to close business.
Persons in want of any article in this line, will find it to their advantage to call and supply themselves.
[no 24--ts] V. Bargamin, Trustee.

div3.head: Virginia and Tennessee rate Road Coupons
div3.p: --The holders of the interest Coupons of the first and second mortgages of this Company, due in New York 1st January, 1861, are hereby notified that they will be cashed on presentation at my office, on and after this date, without discount for pre-payment.
F. G. Morrison,
no 26--tlstJ Treas'r. Va. and Tenn. E. R. Co.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 18, Number 136, page 4.

div3.head: Commercial.
div3.p: Richmond Markets, December 6.
Apples.--Northern $2.50@3.00; Virginia Pippins $2.00 to $4.
Bacon.--Sides 12 ½ cents; Shoulders 10 ¼c.; plain Hams 12; Sugar-cured 13 @13 ½c.; Todd's Sugar-cured Hams 15
Bags — Seamless Bags, 25; Manchester do., 19@23; Gunny do., 12@14
Beans.--White $1.87 ½@1.50 per bushel.
Beeswax.--32 to 33--active.

Brooms.--$2@3.
according to quality.
Buckets, &c.--Painted Buckets $1.87 ½@$2 per dozen; three hoop Painted Paris $2.25@2.50 per dozen; heavy Cedar Tubs, neat, $3.50@5 per nest; heavy Cedar Food Buckets $6.50 per dozen.
Butter.--We quote good Butter at 20 to 25; inferior 8 to 10
Candles.--Tallow 15 per lb.; Jackson's 15; Hall's 16 cts.; Adamantine 20@23; Sperm 45; Patent Sperm 54@56
Cement.--James River $1.70@1.80 per bbl.; Northern Rosendale at $1.70 @1.80.
Coal.--White and Red Ash Anthracite Coal, for grates, $6.50 per cart load of 25 bushels, per ton of 2,340 lbs.; Bituminous Lump $5 per load of 25 bushels; Hall $1.50; Smiths' Coal 12 @14 per bushel.
Coffee.--We quote Rio 14 ½@15 ½c.; Laguayra, none in market; Java 16 ½@17 cts.; Mocha 18 cents. Market firm.
Coke.--For city consumption $5 per cart load of 25 bushels, for soft lump; soft hail $4.50. Hard lump and hail $4.50.
Corn Meal--85 cts. per bushel.
Cotton.--8 ½ to 12 cents.
Cotton Yarns, &c.--Cotton Yarns 21@22 cts.; Cotton Cordage 24 cts.; Seine Twine 27 cts.; Carpet Warp 22 cts.; Wrapping Twine 22 cts.

Dried Fruit.--No arrivals.
We quote nominally $1@1.26 per bushel.
Feathers — In demand at 46 cts. Stock small; better supply.

Fertilizers.--We quote Peruvian $58; Ruffin's Phosphor Peruvian $50 per ton; Aa Mexican $25; Elide Island $48; Patagonian $25; Sombrero $30; Navassa, or Brown Columbian $30; Reese's Manipulated Guano, $50; Rhodes' Super Phosphate of Lime $46.50 per ton; Robinson's Manipulated Guano $50 per ton; Hartman's (Richmond) Ammoniated Super Phosphate Lime $40 per ton; do. Manipulated Guano $50 per ton; do. Bone Dust $38 per ton.

Fish.--New Nova Scotia Herrings, gross, $2.75@$ No. 1 Halifax Cut Herrings $3.26@$3.50 from store.
No North Carolina in market.--Mackerel, large No. 3, new, $8.50; small do., $5.
Flaxseed--$1.20@1.40 per bushel.
Flour.--There is nothing doing in Flour, except in the merest retail way. We quote it lower, however, even in this limited way. We quote Superfine $6.25@6.50; Extra $7 @7.25; Family $7.50@7.75.
Flour Barrels--45 to 50 cts. for city made; Country have sold recently at from 20 to 30 cts.

Fruit.--Oranges; Havana $9 per bbl. Lemons; $4.50@5.00 per box. Raisins; Bunch $2.75@$3; layers $3@3.25.
Prunes 10 to 40 cts. per box, according to quality.
Figs 2 ½ @20 cts. per lb.
Ginseng.--35@40 cents, and in demand.

Grass Seeds--We quote prime Clover Seed 6.25@6.50; nominal.
Timothy 4@ $4.25 per bushel.--Orchard Grass $2.
Gunpowder — Dupont's and Hazard's Sporting $5.75; Blasting $3.75; Eagle Canister $14.25; F Canister $8.25. In quantities of twenty kegs and upwards, 50 cents a keg less.
Hay.--We quote $1.15 per cwt.

Hides — Salted 8 ½@9 cts.; Dry 11@13 cts.; Calf skins, green, $1 @1.12.
South American, none.

Hoop Poles — Flour bbl. $7.50@9 per 1,000; hhds.
poles, $15.
Iron and Nails.--Pig Iron $28@34, as in quality and quantity; Swedes $400 per ton; English Refined $70; Tredegar $85; Common English $60; American country $96. Cut Nails 3 ¼@3 ¼c. per lb.

the New York Journal of commerce, of Wednesday afternoon, says:

q.p:
the pressure among borrowers outside of the Banks has probably been greater to-day than at any previous moment, every one being disposed to wait for further developments in political and financial affairs before embarking in any New undertakings.
Fortunately, the distress is much less than might have been apprehended under such a state of things, as the payments due from all classes of traders are unusually light.
The unfavorable news from New Orleans, communicated yesterday in private dispatches, is confirmed today.
There have been a number of failures, and if the Banks continue specie payments there, it is evident that there must be much distress among the merchants and factors.

bibl.n: the New York Journal of commerce

div3.p: Foreign Exchange is nominal, and, at the moment, is almost entirely unsaleable.
the Stock market is lower, and there has been considerable anxiety to sell.
Boston Weekly Bank Statement, Dec. 5.--the Weekly Statement shows the following footings:

Mobile,Dec. 4.--Cotton — sales to-day of 4,000 bales at 9 ¼@9 ½ for middling; sales of three days 9,000 bales. Receipts 10,000 bales. Sterling Exchange 98@100.
Sight Exchange on New York ½ per cent. discount.

Boston Money Market.--The Banks have but a meagre holding of coin, in view, especially, of the 15 per cent. law, nearly all of them try to keep more or less, and they have no united action, except in the matter of half-bill settlements, a measure of little relief to the public.
About all the real improvement that has recently been exhibited results from the abatement of the mere panic-feeling by the talk of bank union, and because people have got used to secession talk from the leniency of the New York Banks, which have not drawn their Boston balances of late; and from actual discounts obtained in New York by Boston bankers, brokers and merchants, or from those, which somehow or other, have inured to Boston benefit.

The country banks are now drawing heavily, and under the present regime it will be a great thing if the city banks can continue to discount receipts, while it is evident that any further contraction would be dangerous both to debtor and creditor.
Nobody wants specie, for the moment, and the banks hold nearly three millions and a half.
But there is little but stagnation between them and suspension.
With the aid of New York and credit settlements, they could expand moderately and beneficially; but as before remarked, they do not readily act as a unit, and their meetings amount to nothing.
Outside rates are irregular, ranging from 12 to 18 per cent, for paper of about the same quality.
Call loans are not readily effected by street borrowers, and the grand question of who carries all the copper stocks is oftener asked than answered.
New York funds are in fair supply, but full demand, and naturally domestic exchanges must rule against Boston.

We flatter ourselves that the style, fit, and durability of our garments are unsurpassed by any house in the city, and that our advantages in manufacturing clothing are such as to enable us to sell at such reduced prices as cannot be equalled.
Having made more extensive arrangements this season for the supply of the great demands for Clothing than ever before, we hope to receive a large support from all in want of articles in our branch of business, assuring them all that we will do them justice.
We are also prepared to make to order any article of Gent's Wearing Apparel, at short notice.

div3.head: Bellevue Hospital.
div3.p: --This institution, which has been in successful operation seven years, is situated on Church Hill, Richmond, Virginia, in a delightful, airy position, and is furnished with every convenience conducive to the comfort of patients and the successful treatment of medical and surgical diseases.
Rooms have been nicely furnished, suitable to the accommodation of gentlemen who may find it inconvenient to be treated at their private lodgings.
Particular attention will be paid to the lying-in wards, which are very commodious.

Having been heretofore liberally patronized by owners of slaves, both in the city and country, we can, with increased confidence, call their attention to the great advantages afforded by our "Hospital," for the medical and surgical treatment of Slaves, and promise to spare no pains to furnish them proper accommodations and every necessary attention.
terms:

table.head: (payable on the removal of the Patient.)

row.cell: White Patients, in Private Rooms, per week

div3.p:
(For fractions of a week, after the first week, at
the same rates, i. e. 71 cents per day.)
For less than a week, (except in private rooms,) $1 per day, provided that the aggregate shall not exceed the charge for a full week.

This includes all charges for Board, Medical Attendance, Nursing and Medicine.
By an arrangement with the Infirmary of the Medical College, a small additional fee, ranging from $2 to $30, will be charged for Surgical cases.
The particular sum may be ascertained before-hand by application to one of the attending Physicians.
No Small-Pox admitted.

All patients are under our immediate care, one of us visiting the wards once a day, and oftener when necessary; and in cases of difficulty, a consultation of all the physicians is held, without extra charge to the patient.
A resident Physician, two Students and a Matron, have the patients under their immediate supervision, and personally administer all medicines ordered.
When requested, weekly reports will be given of the condition of patients.
Persons in the country, wishing to send patients to our Hospital, may address either of the Physicians, or the Resident Physician.

When desired, we will send a comfortable covered vehicle to any part of the city for patients. --For this purpose, a message left at the Hospital, or a Mr. Thos. Pemberton's, on Main, between 17th and 18th streets, will be attended to.

div3.head: Infirmary of the Medical College.
div3.p: --This Institution, situated at the corner of Marshall and College streets, is fully provided for the accommodation of both White Persons and Negroes, requiring medical treatment.
White Persons who desire it, can be furnished with private Rooms, where they will enjoy every comfort and convenience.

The accommodations for Slaves, as heretofore, are ample, and the attention of owners of negroes, both in the city and country, is again invited to the great advantages afforded by the Infirmary for the Medical and Surgical treatment of this class of patients.
Lying-in Women are also received and carefully attended to.

All patients are under the care of the Professors of the College, who visit the wards daily, aided by an efficient corps of assistants.
In cases of difficulty, a consultation of the Professors is held, without extra charge to the patient.
The charges for Medical Attendance, Board, Nursing and Medicine are as follows:
For less than a week, (except in private rooms,) $1 per day — provided that the aggregate shall not exceed the charge for a full week.

For Surgical Operations, by agreement with the proprietors of the Bellevue Hospital, a small extra charge will be made, varying from $2 to $30, according to the difficulty and importance of the operation.
All charges payable on the removal of the patient.
no case of small Pox, or any other infectious disease, nor any case of Insanity, will be admitted.

div3.head: The Wedding Ring
div3.p:
is emblematic of the marriage relation.
Gold will wear out by friction, abrasion, &c.; but never rusts — never tarnishes — is always bright.
Thus, with life, the Ring is without end; so likewise is the union without interruption or end, except by the death of the parties.

The Wedding Ring being plain, shows that the fair one to whom it is given is, in the estimation of the giver, the most perfect and loveable of her sex, needing not the foreign aid of ornament to render her just the woman for him to love and cherish all his days.

A good assortment of plain Gold Rings, suitable for Wedding Rings, just finished, can be found at 96 Main street, where will be found Watches, Jewelry, Silver Ware, Silver-plated Ware, Spectacles, &c., &c. Watches, Jewelry and Spectacles repaired in the best manner.

Having an experience of 8 years in the business, and knowing the benefit of selling good goods, we are now more sensible than ever of the importance of selling none but good and durable goods, since there is so much of low priced goods in the market, and sold to unsuspecting buyers as first-class goods.
We guarantee all of our goods to be as represented, and most respect fully solicit a call from all in want of first-class goods at low prices.

div3.head: $20 reward
div3.p: --Ran away on Saturday, the 3d inst, from the employment of Dr. John B. Eastham, of Louisa county, a Negro man, named Ralph, belonging to the estate of Jesse Perkins, dec'd.

Ralph is about twenty-two years of age, black, about five feet five inches high; one of his front teeth is out, and the rest are very broad and white.
No peculiar mark about him is remembered, but we think he has a scar between his forefinger and thumb on one of his hands — can't say which.
He, it is said, can write a good hand, and is probably making his way to a free State.--The above reward will be paid for his apprehension in the State and delivery to us, or being placed in a jail so that we get him; or, if taken out of the State and delivered to us, or placed in a jail in this State, so that we get him, a reward of $100 will be paid.
Wm. Crawford,
John R. Quarles,
Frank T. West,
Ex'ors of Jesse Perkins, dec'd.
Trevillian's Depot. Louisa co.,
Nov. 12th, 1860. no 14--ts

div3.head: The Ashland Hotel.

Jno. L. Thompson, Proprietor,
7--ts Ashland., Va.

div3.head: A Card.
div3.p:
--We very earnestly request customers and others, who have our Bags, to send them to us full of grain, if ready to send it, or empty, by the next train.
We are suffering great inconvenience for want of our Bags that are idle in various hands who have neglected to return them.
In a short time we must make up bag accounts and charge the holders with them.
When we send bags to any person, they should be returned promptly.

Much of the wheat we receive is damp.
Farmers ought to dry it at home.
Barns, granaries and "all out of doors" are big enough to spread it in, Farmers lose immensely by inattention to this point.

We have fallen on perilous times, when debt is fearful.
Filling orders for guano, &c., on the faith of growing crops, won't do for those who have to buy them on time.
A safe principle of individual economy is to make money before we spend it.

--Stebbins, Pullen & Co. will, from this day, offer their entire stock of Fancy Goods, Vases, &c., at greatly reduced prices for cash.
Now is the time to make your purchases for the holidays.
Call early.
Stebbins, Pullen & Co.,
Corner 9th and Broad sts.

div3.head: We have some Great bargains again
div3.p:
--look at Our price List.--Clear nice Tumblers from 37 cts, a dozen up; Goblets from $2 a dozen up; Preserve Dishes, 10 cts. and higher, worth a great deal more; Kerosene Lamps from 75 cts. up to some very rich patterns — the best burners out, worth most twice the money; all other Glassware in proportion; Dinner, Tea and Chamber Sets, bought at a great sacrifice from a New York importer, which we offer at an astonishing low figure.
Our Vases, Motto Cups and other Parlor Ornaments defy competition.
Whoever looks at our assortment of Britannia, Albata and Silver-plated Ware, as also Table Cutlery, says that we are hard to beat in that line.
All kinds of House-Furnishing Goods, in Wooden and Willow-ware, Brushes, Tinware, Waiters, Looking-Glasses, (which we make to order, any size required.) besides an immense variety in Fancy Goods and Toys, &c.
Schaap & Co., corner Broad and 3d sts.

div3.head: New Goods of direct importation.
div3.p: --Rich China decorated Dinner Sets, of twenty different patterns; elegantly decorated and plain Tea Sets; White Granite Dinner Ware, Tea Ware and Toilet Ware; Fancy Goods; Rich Plated Ware; Cut and Mounted Glassware, Lamps, Chandeliers; House-furnishing Goods, &c.
Visitors to the Fair are respectfully solicited to examine our stock, which has been purchased exclusively for cash, and is therefore offered on the most liberal terms.
Stebbins, Pullen & Co.,
101 Broad st., cor. of 9th,

div3.head: To housekeepers.
div3.p: --By late arrivals, we offer a splendid variety of French Dinner and Tea Sets; White Granite Ware, in sets or single pieces; Fancy Toilet Ware, of new designs; Glass Ware, of every description; Silver-Plated Ware; Ivory Handle and Common Knives and Forks; Bronze Iron Hat Stands; Tea Trays; Britannia Coffee and Tea Urns; Oyster Dishes; Fenders; Fire Irons; Coal Hods; Foot Warmers; Japanned Toilet Ware; Gas Fixtures; Mirrors; together with a magnificent stock of rich Fancy Goods, all of which we offer as low as such goods can be obtained.
T. A. Bulkley & Co., 127 Main st.

div3.head: Tappahannock Stage line.
div3.p:
--On and after Friday, the 6th, the Stage for Tappahannock will leave Richmond only on Thursdays and Fridays.
[de 5 --12t] Bell & Boughan.

div3.head: Winter Schedule.
div3.p: Richmond and York River Railroad.--cheap and Attractive Route from Richmond to Old Point, Norfolk, Portsmouth, Eastern Shore and Matthews. --Fare $2--Dinner Extra.

On and after Thursday, Dec. 13th, 1860, Passenger Trains will leave Richmond daily, (except Sundays,) at 8 o'clock A. M., stopping on signal at Fair Oaks, Meadow, Dispatch, Tunstall's, Fish Hall, Cohoke, Sweet Hall, and Roanoke, and arrive at West Point at 9:45 A. M.

The fast and commodious Steamer West Point, Capt. J. C. Rowe, will leave King and Queen Court-House Landing on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays, at 8:30 A. M., connecting with the cars at West Point, and stopping upon signal only at Water Fence, Shepherd's, Moody's, Cappahoosic, Bigler's, Gloucester Point, Yorktown and Old Point, and arrive at Norfolk and Portsmouth at 3:30 P. M. Returning, the Steamer will leave Norfolk and Portsmouth on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays, at 8 A. M., landing as above, and connecting with the cars at West Point at 2 P. M., and arrive at Richmond at 3:45 P. M.
On Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays, the Passenger Train will leave West Point for Richmond at 10 A. M., and arrive at 11:45 A. M., stopping on signal as above.
Passengers for the Eastern Shore can leave Norfolk on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays by the Steamer Northampton, Captain McCarrick, and for Matthews on Thursdays and Saturdays.

row.cell: Fare from Richmond or any point on York River to Eastern Shore
Fare from Richmond to West Point, or from West Point to Richmond and return next day or train

div3.p: Freight received Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays, until 3:30 P. M., at Richmond, and on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays, until 3:30 P. M., at West Point.
Accommodation and Freight Train will leave Richmond Tuesdays. Thursdays, and Saturdays, at 4 P. M., stopping on signal, at all the Stations, for freight and passengers.
Fare from King and Queen C. H., and other points on Mattaponi River to Norfolk or Richmond, $2.
Passengers for Williamsburg will take Stage at Bigler's, for Gloucester C. H., at Cappahoosic, and for Salada and Urbanna, at West Point.
Sunday Trains discontinued after Dec. 9th.
de 6--ts R. H. Temple, Sup't.

div3.head: Special notice,
div3.p: --Owing to the stringency in the money market and the heavy discounts charged in consequence, the Agents of this Company are instructed, on and after this date, until further notice, not to receive any moneys in payment of fares and freights, but Virginia Bankable funds and specie.
Samuel Ruth, Sup't.
Office R., F. & P. R. R. Co.,
Richmond, 24th Nov., '60. no 24 --ts

div3.head:
Notice.
1860.
div3.p:
to Passengers going North.--New Arrangement.--important to Travelers.--through Tickets and through Checks.--Great Northern Route — Carrying the great United States Mail.
Twice daily (Sunday night excepted) between Richmond, Alexandria, Washington, Baltimore, Philadelphia, New York, and all important points West, via Acquis Creek and Washington, over the Richmond, Fredericksburg & Potomac Railroad, to the Potomac river, 75 miles, and by splendid and comfortable steamers thence to Washington, 55 miles, in all 156 miles in seven hours; being a comfortable and perfectly safe rate of speed.
Hours of departure: 6:30, A. M., and 7 P. M.
Baggage, under charge of Special Agents, Checked through to Washington, Baltimore, Philadelphia and New York.

Through Tickets can be secured to the following points — viz: Baltimore, Philadelphia, Cincinnati, Columbus, Indianapolis, Cairo, Dayton, Jeffersonville, Rock Island, Zanesville, Washington New York, St. Louis, Chicago, Pittsburg, Louisville, Decatur, Newark and Vincennes.
Passengers breakfast and sup at Ashland and dine on board the comfortable steamer between Acquis Creek and Washington.

Persons wishing to obtain tickets for servants for Washington city and points further North, must, in all cases, be vouched for by some responsible white citizen of Richmond,in person, known to the officers of the Road, as no Tickets will be sold if applied for by letter.
For further information, apply at this office, Broad street, Shockoe Hill.
Jas. B. Winston, Gen'l Ticket Ag't.

div3.head: Virginia Central Railroad.--Fall Arrangement.
div3.p: --On and after Monday, the 1st of October, the Mail and Passenger Train will leave Richmond daily, (except Sunday,) at 6.30 A. M., for Staunton and all intermediate way stations, connecting at Gordonsville with the Orange and Alexandria Railroad Trains for Alexandria and intermediate stations, and at Charlottesville with their trains for Lynchburg and all points West and South-west of that place; and every other day, viz: Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays, for Jackson's River and stations West of Staunton.
Harman & Brown's Stages connect with the train at Staunton on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays, and at Goshen on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays, for Lexington.

Harman, Mason & Co.'s Stages connect with the train on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays, at Millboro', for the Warm Springs; and at Jackson's River, for the White Sulphur Springs, Lewisburg, &c. Returning, the Mail Train leaves Jackson's River on Mondays. Wednesdays and Fridays, at 3.15 P. M. for Staunton.

A Freight Train, with a passenger car attached, will leave Waynesboro', at 7.45, and Staunton at 9.45 A. M., on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays for Jackson's River.
Returning, leave Jackson's River on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays at 7.45 A. M., for Waynesboro'.

Through tickets for the Warm and White Sulphur Springs, Lexington, Lewisburg, &c.; also, for Winchester, Lynchburg, Bonsack's, Salem, Shawsville, Christiansburg, Bristol, Knoxville, Dalton, Chattanooga, Nashville, Grand Junction, Memphis, Canton, New Orleans, and all important points in the Southwest, can be procured at the ticket office.
oc 1--ts Thos. Dodamead, Gen'l Supt.

div3.head: Richmond and Danville Railroad--Express Freight and Accommodation Trains.
div3.p: --On and after Monday, Oct. 1st, an Express, Freight and Accommodation Train will leave Richmond daily (Sundays excepted,) for Lynchburg and intermediate points, leaving Richmond at 4 P. M., and arriving in Lynchburg at 3 A. M., in time to connect with the passenger train going west on the Virginia and Tennessee Railroad.
Returning, leave Lynchburg at 7.25 P. M., immediately on the arrival of the train from the west, and arrive in Richmond at 6.10 A. M.
se 29--ts C. G. Talcott, Supt.

div3.head: Travelers 1860.
div3.p: to the North.--Northern Central Railway.--Trains leave Calvert Station, Baltimore, daily, (except Sunday,) at 8.30 A. M., and at 5.30 P. M., for Niagara Falls, (fare only ten dollars,) Buffalo, Owego, Oswego, Toronto, Hamilton, all parts of Western New York and Canada, for Detroit, Chicago, Cincinnati, St. Louis, and all parts of the West, North west and Southwest.
Travelers can go to Detroit, Chicago, Milwaukee, &c., via Niagara Falls, at the same cost as by any other route.

A new route to New York is now open by this Road, via Harrisburg and Jersey City, with only one change of cars.
Fare $6. Take the 8.30 A. M. train and go through by daylight, over first-class Roads and through a beautiful country.
Try it.
Buy tickets only to Baltimore.
Jas. C. Clarke, Sup't.
John T. Rigney, Assistant Sup't. je 13--1y

div3.p: --Freight Boats to Lynchburg three Times A week--Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays.
Boat Tempest, Capt. Thos. Emett.
Boat Merchant, Capt. Geo. C. Layne.
Boat Bristol, Capt. Chas. J. Johnson.
Boat J. J. Irby, Capt. Wm. F. Cleveland.
Boat Fame, Capt. Wm. H. Parsons.
Boat Olivia, Capt. J. J. Peters.

These Boats are all of the first class, commanded by careful and experienced Captains, and leave promptly as advertised.
The subscriber thankful for past favors, begs a continuance of the same.
Wm. P. Cox, Agent.

At the Shed.
Deck st., in rear of old Gas Works.

div3.head: Notice to the public!
div3.p: --New and important Arrangement, 1860.--The Adams Express Company respectfully announce to the public that they have arranged to run their Express Twice Daily from New York, Philadelphia and Baltimore to Richmond, thereby affording unusual facilities for obtaining their freight and packages in the shortest possible time.

Expresses leave New York at 1.5 and 6 o'clock P. M. Expresses leave Philadelphia at 8 A. M. and 11 P. M. Expresses leave Baltimore at 4.20 A. M. and 4.20 P. M., arriving in Richmond at 3.30 A. M. and 2 P. M.
Expresses leave Richmond for New York, Philadelphia and Baltimore, and all points North and West, at 6.30 A. M. and 6.30 P. M.
Freight and packages should in all cases be at our office one hour before the departure of the Trains.
Expresses for the South leave Richmond Twice Daily, at 4.30 A. M. and 2.45 P. M.

The Adams Express Company feel that they can guarantee to the public civility, attention and satisfaction in all their intercourse with their officers in Richmond, and nothing will be left undone on their part to meet the wants of their customers.

Freight and packages arriving by the Express from the North at 3 o'clock P. M. will be delivered immediately, thereby giving to our customers an advance of twelve hours over our arrangements heretofore.

Steamer Expresses, to and from New York, Semi-Weekly.
Freights delivered immediately upon the arrival of the ship.
heavy and light Freights, Packages, money, Bonds, Legal Documents, &c., forwarded with safety and dispatch to all parts of the United States, Canada and Europe.
notes, Drafts and Bills, with or without Goods, collected at all accessible points throughout the United States, and prompt returns guaranteed.
Slaves forwarded by each of our Expresses, in charge of careful and reliable messengers.
Tobacco and other samples carried at unusual low rates.
All freights promptly called for and delivered without extra charge
For further information, please call at our office, 202 Main street.
"Adams Express Company."
au 7--ts W. H. Trego. Sup't.
